item.title: Factorization conditions for nonlinear second-order differential equations. (arXiv:2211.01541v1 [nlin.SI])
item.description: For the case of nonlinear second-order differential equations with a constant coefficient of the first derivative term and polynomial nonlinearities, the factorization conditions of Rosu and Cornejo-Perez are approached in two ways: (i) by commuting the subindices of the factorization functions in the two factorization conditions and (ii) by leaving invariant only the first factorization condition achieved by using monomials or polynomial sequences. For the first case the factorization brackets commute and the generated equations are only equations of Ermakov-Pinney type. The second modification is non commuting, leading to nonlinear equations with different nonlinear force terms, but the same first-order part as the initially factored equation. It is illustrated for monomials with the examples of the generalized Fisher and FitzHugh-Nagumo initial equations. A polynomial sequence example is also included.

item.title: Spectral theory of the Nazarov-Sklyanin Lax operator. (arXiv:2211.01586v1 [math.CO])
item.description: In their study of Jack polynomials, Nazarov-Sklyanin introduced a remarkable new graded linear operator $\mathcal{L}: F[w] \rightarrow F[w]$ where $F$ is the ring of symmetric functions. In this paper, we (1) establish a cyclic decomposition $F[w] \cong \bigoplus_{\lambda} Z(j_{\lambda}, \mathcal{L})$ of the domain of $\mathcal{L}$ into finite-dimensional $\mathcal{L}$-cyclic subspaces in which Jack polynomials $j_{\lambda}$ may be taken as cyclic vectors and (2) prove that the restriction of $\mathcal{L}$ to each $Z(j_{\lambda}, \mathcal{L})$ has simple spectrum given by the anisotropic contents $[s]$ of the addable corners $s$ of the Young diagram of $\lambda$. Our proofs of (1) and (2) rely on the commutativity and spectral theorem for the integrable hierarchy of $\mathcal{L}$, both established by Nazarov-Sklyanin. Finally, we derive and conjecture several properties of the $\mathcal{L}$-eigenfunctions $\psi_{\lambda}^s$ which satisfy $\psi_{\lambda}^s|_{w=0} = j_{\lambda}$.
item.dc:creator: Ryan Mickler, Alexander Moll

item.title: Integrable Floquet systems related to logarithmic conformal field theory. (arXiv:2206.14277v2 [quant-ph] UPDATED)
item.description: We study an integrable Floquet quantum system related to lattice statistical systems in the universality class of dense polymers. These systems are described by a particular non-unitary representation of the Temperley-Lieb algebra. We find a simple Lie algebra structure for the elements of Temperley-Lieb algebra which are invariant under shift by two lattice sites, and show how the local Floquet conserved charges and the Floquet Hamiltonian are expressed in terms of this algebra. The system has a phase transition between local and non-local phases of the Floquet Hamiltonian. We provide a strong indication that in the scaling limit this non-equilibrium system is described by the logarithmic conformal field theory.
item.dc:creator: Vsevolod I. Yashin, Denis V. Kurlov, Aleksey K. Fedorov, Vladimir Gritsev
